background_description: You are an artisan of the arcane, a smith of subtle forces. In the crucible of your workshop, the laws that govern this world are warped to suit your needs.

options.description: There was an explosion, and you lost your sense of smell. Well, almost: you can sniff out gold as a pig does truffles. Take a tin of snuff to dampen the impact. Without it you are deprived

You dematerialized a beloved pet. Now it follows you around, invisible but always present. Although it cannot interact with the physical realm, you are able to share its senses (add a Fatigue each time). It follows basic commands.
You were exposed to a long-acting truth serum whose effects have yet to wear off. The disorder has its advantages: you cannot repeat lies you’ve heard, either.
You were adept at creating fake gold, which is almost as good. Eventually, your ruse was discovered and you had to make a hasty retreat. Take a heavy metal ingot and gold powder.
Your recipe worked, but a rival stole the blueprint before your claims could be proven. Take a prototype blunderbuss (d12, blast, bulky) and a thirst for revenge.
Ridiculed for discovering how to turn gold into lead, you were a laughing stock. Take a bottle of universal solvent (2 uses) that dissolves anything it touches into its constituent parts.

table2.question: What alchemical marvel is the product of your latest ingenuity? (d6)

options.description: Pyrophoric Gel: A sticky green fluid that catches fire when exposed to air. It lasts for 8 hours and cannot be extinguished.
Blast Sphere: A head-sized iron ball filled with explosive powder that detonates on impact. d12, blast, bulky
Aqua Vita: Purifies any liquid, converting it to pure water. Drinking it cures 1d6 STR. 1 use.
Mimic Stone: Records a short phrase that can later be played back.
Spark Dust: Ignites easily and quickly. Useful for starting a fire or as an incendiary device. 3 uses.

Homunculus: A miniature clay replica of yourself that follows your every command to the letter. It hates being enthralled to you and complains bitterly whenever possible. Any damage done to the homunculus is also done to you.

background_description: You walk the line between healer and harrower, knowing the frailty of the flesh but also the secrets that lay within. With the right tools, life and death are merely words.

options.description: You have a replacement eye that can magnify objects, acts as a telescope, and provides minimal night vision. You cannot wear anything metal on your head, and the presence of strong magnets make you _deprived_.
One foot is mostly metal (kick, d6), and you treat some tough terrain as Easy. Carry an Oil Can (6 uses). Without a daily application you are _deprived_ and noisy.
One of your fingers has been swapped, the bone replaced by gold and iron. Take a Hook and a Screwdriver that can attach to the fingertip.

Both ears have been surgically enhanced, tripling your hearing. You can focus on a specific sound at a great distance, such as a conversation. You wear an ear flap to protect against sudden loud noises (WIL save to avoid temporary paralysis).
Your chest is lined with alchemical sigils, toughening the skin (Armor 1). Wearing other metallic armor nullifies the effect.
One arm is fully metal (fist, d8), and comes off at the shoulder (bulky when carried). It can move independently if you are within sight of it.

table2.question: What rare tool is essential to your work? (d6)

options.description: Regrowth Salve: Regrows a body part over the course of a day.
Graftgrub: A small worm that can fuse inanimate objects with parts of the body. 1 use.
Woundwax: Heals wounds from fire or chemicals (restoring full STR), but nothing else. 2 uses.
Quicksilver: A stimulant. Go first in combat, and automatically pass any WIL saves for one hour. Addictive: Save STR or become deprived after 24 hours without it. 4 uses.
Pneuma Pump: Portable iron lungs (bulky). Enables life-saving surgery or underwater breathing.
Lodestone: Draws out dangerous elements from the body and acts as a powerful magnetic force.

background_description: You alone can walk among the creatures of the wild, fearless and in control. You share a connection with animals that others can only dream of... so long as you don't become their snack.

table1.question: What creature is your specialty? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Arachnids: Take a Quick-Flame Rod and an Oil Can (6 uses). It can destroy a large spider nest in seconds.
Felines: Take a sack of Whiskerwort. Its odor can calm and control even the largest of cats.
Canines: Take a wreath of Wolfsbane and a Large Net. Effective against werewolves as well.
Birds: Take a Warble-Whistle (3 charges). It can imitate any bird call, and can even be used to send simple messages. Recharge: Feed a baby bird as its mother would, then blow.
Rodents: Take a Pan Flute that emits a high-pitched sound that only rodents can hear. So long as you play, they will follow. Even to their deaths.
Serpents: Take a Warming Stone that generates an irresistible heat, and a vial of Antitoxin (2 uses).

table2.question: What do creatures of the wild understand that your kind do not? Roll 1d6:

options.description: There is far more to the world than meets the eye. With quiet concentration, you can borrow the senses of a nearby creature of your specialty.
The behavior of beasts is a language in itself. When observing beasts of your specialty, you gain insight into weather patterns and impending disasters.
The pulse of the hunt is a powerful impulse. You have a sense for when predators, even those not of your specialty, are near.
You know some lands intimately. Your chance of becoming lost in a terrain dominated by the beasts of your specialty is reduced by one step (e.g. 4-in-6 becomes 3-in-6).
Nature's symphony can be heard if you attune to its rhythm. When surrounded by creatures of your specialty they can alert you to approaching danger before it arrives.
Survival is about adaptability. Once per day, you may take on a simple feature from a creature of your speciality (webbed fingers, night vision, etc.). Add a Fatigue each time.

background_description: You are a shepherd to the departed. You listen to the final whispers of the dead as they descend into the cold, unyielding earth. You know that to fully celebrate the gift of life, we must honor its finale as well.

table1.question: What did you take from the dead? Roll 1d6:

options.description: A crow-shaped amulet. You can ask a question of the dead, but must add a Fatigue each time. They do not always speak truthfully.

A mortal wound from a freed revenant. You were healed, but the disfigurement has made you a pariah. You require neither air nor sustenance, but are still subject to pain and death. Trapped between, the dead see you as one of their own.

A Blood Pail (bulky) from a local death-cult. Empty its contents to summon a creature built from items buried below (bones, rocks, pottery, etc). It obeys your command, but if destroyed you permanently lose 1d4 STR. It has 6 HP, 1 Armor, 13 STR, 11 DEX, 4 WIL, shard fists (d8). Recharge: Fill the bucket with the blood of a dying warrior.
A burial wagon (+6 slots, slow) from your last job. It came with a stubborn old donkey (+4 slots, +2 slots if pulling wagon).

The Detect Magic spellbook, stolen from an ancient library. Your family worked in service to an obscure underworld deity, but you lost your faith. Though exiled, you continue to serve, even as an apostate.
A plague doctor's mask, after its owner succumbed to the disease that wiped out everyone you once knew. They should have kept it on.

table2.question: What tool was invaluable in your work? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Manacles: Though old, it's still effective even against the very strong. You don't have the key.
Sponge: Supposedly made from the remains of a rare sea creature. It never seems to dry out.
Pulley: Great for moving gravestones, rocks, or even bodies.
Incense: Perfect for rituals, or to keep the flies at bay. Cools the blood.
Crowbar: d6 damage. Sometimes you just need to get the damn thing open!
Repellent: Powerful stuff. Its faded label makes it unclear what it is actually meant to repel, though. Perhaps everything. 3 uses.

background_description: You live in the grey space between those who have power and those who don’t. You find opportunity where others see only chaos. With nimble fingers, you unburden both the richest merchant and the lowliest guard.

table1.question: What was your last big job? Roll 1d6:

options.description: A noble's summer home. The place was full of fancy wine (+20gp) but not much else. Take Fence Cutters.
A bank (you were caught). You bear a brand only visible by firelight, and anyone that sees the mark can ask you for a beer. Take Retractable Wires.
A guild warehouse. Take a Ladder (bulky, 10ft) and Blinding Powder (1 use).
Moneylender. Someone beat you to the job, but left behind a Scroll of Arcane Eye (petty). _Arcane Eye_: You can see through a magical floating eyeball that flies around at your command.
Constable's quarters. You escaped, but left some friends behind. Take Strong Silk Rope (30ft) and a queasy feeling.
A university. You were seen, but not pursued. You still don't know why. Take Smoke Pellets (3 uses).
Catring: 2 charges. Climb up walls and fall safely. Recharge: Place the ring on a stray cat's tail.
Gildfinger: 1 charge. A finger glove that mimics any mundane key. Recharge: bundle it with at least 100gp for a night.
Glimpse Glass: 3 charges. A monocle that lets you see through walls or other obstructions. It shatters after the last use.
Sweetwhistle: 1 charge. Listeners hear a soft, familiar voice in the distance that they cannot resist following. Recharge: Lose a dear memory (describe it).
Vagrant's Veil: 1 charge. Wear it to blend seamlessly into crowds, appearing as a simple pauper. Recharge: Donate the day's winnings to the poor. Petty.
Smokestack Marble: 3 uses. Crush to release a dense cloud of smoke that follows you. Petty.

background_description: Protectors of the harvest, defense against pests, thieves, and beasts. A position of great honor, while it lasts: many guardians do not live out their natural lives. Roll a second time on the Bonds table.

table1.question: What got the better of you? Roll 1d6:

options.description: A voracious swarm of pests that swallowed crops and animals alike. With nothing to defend, you left. Take Gale Seed Extract (3 uses).  Ingesting one lets you sprint with a speed four times your regular rate. Afterward you add two Fatigue.
A crop spirit, angered by a poor tithing. The fires consumed nearly everything, and afterwards you were able to gather a pouch of Fireseeds (d8, blast, 4 uses).
An antlered, toothy demon that nearly ended you. Take the blood-stained Bone Knife that saved your life (d6). On Critical Damage, its next attack becomes enhanced from contact with blood.
The Withering, a type of stem rot from The Roots. Take a Diseased Crop (6 uses) that quickly decays any plant it touches.

Wolves, or so you thought. You are now a Werewolf [8 HP, 15 STR, 14 DEX, claws (d6+d6) or bite (d8)]. Your WIL remains the same. You can turn at will (once per day) but must make a WIL save to revert. Anyone left alive from your attacks must make a WIL save to avoid infection.
Crop thieves. Not all of them survived, but you were outnumbered. Take a +d4 HP and a Hilted Broadsword (d8).

table2.question: What tool saved your life? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Bloodvine Whip: d8 damage. On Critical Damage it drains the target's blood, granting the weapon's next attack the blast quality.
Clatter Keeper: A hand-cranked device that emits a loud noise, frightening away most creatures.
Sun Stick: Provides ample warmth and light for up to one hour. Recharge: Leave in heavy sunlight for a full day.
Root Tether: When thrown, binds up to a wolf-sized creature to the soil for a short time.
Greenwhistle: A small flute that calms plants, making passage through areas heavy with plant life a bit easier.
Everbloom Band: A circlet adorned with flowers that never wilt. On taking Critical Damage the flowers dissolve into dust, but you act as if your save succeeded (STR loss still occurs).

background_description: You strike from afar, but that does not make you a coward. You are a musician, the song of your bowstring nought but a warning, singing the silent promise of a quick death.

table1.question: How did you earn your bow? Roll 1d6:

options.description: War. If you are first to attack, your bow gains the blast property for the first round.
Falconry. You keep a falcon [3 hp, 5 STR, 16 DEX, 4 WIL, claws (d6+d6), bite (d6)]. It only eats live game.
Hunting. When taking the [Supply](https://cairnrpg.com/wip/2e/wilderness-exploration/#supply) action your ability to secure Rations increases by one step (e.g. 1d4 becomes 1d6).
Tournaments. Attacks with your bow are enhanced if the target is immobile.
Training. If you are the first to attack, melee attacks against you are impaired until you take STR damage.
Scouting. When taking the [Travel](https://cairnrpg.com/wip/2e/wilderness-exploration/#travel) action, your presence decreases the chance of getting lost by one step (e.g. 4-in-6 becomes 3-in-6).

table2.question: What kind of wood is your bow made from? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Western Yew (d6, bulky). Can be wielded as a blunt weapon (d6). Noisy.
Sessile Oak (d8, bulky). Slams into targets. On Critical Damage something is torn off.
Stone Pine (d6, bulky). Produces one use of Sticky Sap per day. It is highly explosive.
White Ash (d6, bulky). Can be used in place of a shield in melee combat (+1 Armor).
Striped Bamboo (d6). Collapsible, it only requires one slot (but still requires both hands).
Wych Elm (d6, bulky). Protects the bearer from poisons and toxins, so long as they are holding it.

background_description: An odd birthmark, a strange smell: somehow, the touch of elsewhere still lingers. You'll never fit in, at least not where you're at. Roll on the Omens table, but keep the results private for now.

Heirloom amulet.description: glows in the presence of magic

options.description: An old hunter. You were both quite happy, until it all ended. Take a Weathered Longbow (d8, bulky) and a Leather Jerkin (1 Armor).
A wizened apothecary, who taught you the healing arts but maintained a clinical detachment. Take a Healing Ungent (restores d4 STR).
A druid, who taught you the language of trees. When it came time to leave you took with you only a Gnarled Staff (d8) and the promise that one day you would return.

A gruff blacksmith from a sleepy river town. You were always kept at arm's length. Now the forge is cold, and you've moved on. Take a Smith's Hammer (d6) and a set of Oft-mended Chain Mail (2 Armor, bulky).
A troupe of traveling entertainers. For a time, they were like family to you. One day you woke up and they were gone with no explanation. Take a Storybook, a Dagger (d6), and some burning questions.
The monks of a secluded forest monastery. When their rules became too strict, and you snuck away. Take a Monk's Habit (warm, petty) and a Spellbook of Control Plants.

table2.question: What keeps bad tidings at bay? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Pipeweed. Your good luck charm. Conversations tend to flow more easily after a smoke.
Stink Jar. Shattering this jar releases an odor so foul all nearby must make a STR save or immediately vomit.
Ivy Worm. A green worm often mistaken for a weed. Swallowed whole, it absorbs any toxins or rot in the body before exiting through the usual way.
Dream Stone. A smooth blue stone that helps recall dreams more clearly. Overuse can cause dream-addiction.
Drowning Rod. A finger-sized wooden stick that doubles in size each time it is fully submerged in water. It does not shrink down again.
Rabbit's Foot. You were wearing it when they found you. They say it is the foot of she who left you, and that it protects you from witch magic.

background_description: You follow the whisperings of the deep earth, the rhythmic pulse of the mycelium forest that grows beneath the surface. The dark holds no terror for you. Also, you really love mushrooms.

table1.question: What strange fungi did you discover? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Shrieking Trumpet. When exposed to light it screams so loudly that all nearby attacks (including your own) are impaired.
Torch Fungus. When crushed it creates a heatless light for ten minutes.
Murderous Truffle. Pungent, highly toxic, and very rare (worth 50gp to assassins).  Illegal pretty much everywhere.
Hellcap. Exposure to its aroma causes intense nausea and vomiting. Either way, it clears the room. Bottled.
Sproutcup. Ingest to shrink down to the size of a mouse (your belongings stay the same size). You return to normal size within the hour, often in fits and starts.
Rootflower. A white fungus found only on corpses deep underground. Ingest to restore d6 WIL. You will dream of the dead, and their stories.

table2.question: What keeps you sane, even in utter darkness? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Glowsnail. Casts a soft, bioluminescent light. Feeds on one ration every two days.
Silk Moth Shawl. A weatherproof blanket, it can also douse a fire without being damaged.
Milkflower. A gentle stimulant. Chewing makes you immune to panic for the next hour.
Luxcompass. Hums softly as it moves closer to the Sun. Eventually, the noise becomes unbearably loud.
Sloth-Tarp. A tough and weatherproof fabric, useful for hanging off trees. When inside, take +1 Armor.
Miner's Grease. Great for dislodging a gem, tool, or limb from a tight crack. Highly explosive.

background_description: You delve deep into The Woods, prying its secrets from between rough boughs and whispering leaves. In this verdant kingdom, you are no mere scholar, but its confidant as well.

Twine bauble.description: A silver circle 50ft across appears on the ground. Choose one species that cannot cross it.

table1.question: How have The Woods failed you? Roll 1d6:

options.description: An ill-tempered forest spirit cursed you for stealing, marking you as an enemy of their kind.
A close friend, swallowed whole. Now you see their face in any tea you brew.
You were poisoned, losing your sense of taste and smell. You can now withstand noxious fumes.
Your radical experiments turned your skin green, and you now gain nourishment as a plant. You don't need Rations, but a day without sufficient sunlight and water leaves you deprived.
Your impressive corpseflower won a local contest, then promptly killed a judge. You fled, but not without the Prize Money and a warrant for your arrest.
You created a restorative tincture that also caused accidental infertility.

table2.question: What keeps you safe while in The Woods? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Amadou. A vermillion fungus that catches fire quite easily.
Delphinium. Breathe water for up to one hour. Can be divided into fractional doses.
Tacky Stalk. A woody reed that hardens into a permanent adhesive when chewed.
Wisp Lantern. Caged in wrought iron, provides a dim light so long as the wisp is able to feed on nearby pain and fear.
Seed Bomb. A canvas sack that explode on impact, scattering seeds.
Briarvine. Entangles any creature up to horse size.

background_description: Born of both the mortal world and the unseen, a crossing of veils that makes you an enigma to many. You are both a conduit and a caution of what happens when two worlds collide.

table1.question: What did you bring back from the Unseelie Court? Roll 1d6:

options.description: A Black Rose Fiddle. Its music causes intense sadness and immobility in nearby mortals. You don't know how to play.
Paper legs. You are extremely light, and can fall a few stories without getting hurt. Try to avoid tearing them or getting them wet.
A Living Nightmare that dwells within you, but manifests whenever you are in danger. It disappears on Critical Damage, re-appearing again on the next full moon.
A Raven Familiar. It speaks as an intelligent being and is entirely devoted to you.
A Briar Thorn. It can pierce any organic material but leaves no trace of the intrusion.
A Fae creature's True Name. Use it to summon its owner for an act of great service, but only once.

table2.question: What concoction do you carry, and what rare ingredients did you gather to make it? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Rebirth Ash. Remnants of a bark spirit. Sprinkle to reignite a fire or return to life a creature. 3 uses.
Glamour Feather. Plume of a firebird. Can make any creature appear as someone else. 1 use.
Hawthorn Seed. An acorn from the other side. When planted it sprouts a luxurious shelter. 1 use.
Stonetree Sap. Sap obtained in exchange for blood. Hardens when rubbed on any surface. 3 uses.
Nightdust Powder. The ritual burning of six owls. When tossed in the air, day turns to night. 2 uses.
Hex Stone. Removed from its iron tin, it can absorb the effects of an active magical effect. 1 use.

background_description: You are a mere digit on the unerring hand of justice. You go where others fear to tread, unyielding and unbroken.

table1.question: To which order do you belong? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Order of the Crossroads. Take a Pocket Leyfinder. It points to nearby ley lines and other sources of arcane power.
Order of the Bleeding Star. Take a Star-Iron Mace. It shines faintly in darkness.
Order of the Glass Sigil. Take a short sword and chainmail. You have contacts in most towns.
Order of the Blank Eye. Take a Voidglass Shard. Peer through it to see invisible marks and creatures.
Order of Canaas. Once per day you can change into a wolf.
Order of the Silent Veil. Take a Quell Stone wrapped in burlap. Extinguishes any nearby flames.
Honesty. Attacks against you of a certain type are impaired.
Poverty. You carry the Disassemble Spellbook.
Selflessness. You are immune to mind-altering magical effects.
Mercy. Attacks with a certain weapon are enhanced.
Charity. Once per day you can shrug off a Fatigue.
Valor. The first time you inflict Critical Damage you receive d4 HP.

background_description: What inspires the soul more than song, words, and spectacle? Why practice for years to master the arcane when you've already got real magic inside?

table1.question: What happened at your final performance? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Despite your training in the deadly arts, an actor died and you were blamed. Take a light-weight Rapier (d6) and a false identity.
The crowd loved your catchy tune about a noble and his romantic failings. The noble in question, not so much. Take the Read Mind Spellbook and a warrant for your arrest.

Your debut composition reduced the audience to a gibbering mess, murmuring of bright creatures descending from the night sky. Later you noticed that the notes resembled stellar constellations. Take a Book On Astronomy, and a lot of questions.

You mocked a forgotten trickster god, and were cursed for it. You speak only in perfect rhyme. Ironically, this has only made you more popular among your peers. Take a Thesaurus (20gp). Without it you are deprived.
You were scarred in an on-stage accident. The crowd cheered, thinking it was part of the act. Take well-worn Stage Mail (1 Armor), a memorable scar, and a fear of applause.

Your respectable puppeteering skills were matched only by your mimicry. You were so good you were branded a witch (literally) and banished. Take an Uncanny Hand-Puppet and a Rabbit Skull (petty, sewn with grass) that protects against charms.

table2.question: What trinket were you unable to leave behind? Roll 1d6:

options.description: False Cuffs: Comfortable, realistic-looking cuffs. Only you know the trick to get out of them.
Pocket Theatre: A set of small puppets and folding stage. Good for quick distractions.
Ghost Violin: A dark grey violin that plays a haunting tune, mirrored by an invisible, distant twin.
Tragic Tales: Banned in proper company, it becomes less bawdy and more harrowing towards the end. Worth 100gp.
Mythos Mask: A plaster mask that allows one to take on a monster's countenance. Once it comes off, add a Fatigue.
Rebreak Glass: A wine flute that can be broken multiple times, reforming after 24 hours. Makes a really loud noise.

background_description: You are known by the smell of molten metal and the jingle of tin. You are not a mere merchant, but an artisan of fire and metal.

options.description: You build small contraptions for local guilds (and don't ask too many questions). Given time and materials, you can open almost any door or vault.
You deal in home goods and tools, hawking your wares to townspeople across the lands. You are fluent in the Traveller's Cant.
items: 20gp worth of items from gear table

options.description: You were a military smelter, before peace destroyed your livelihood. Given time and adequate materials, you can repair armor.
You sell rare and quality items to monasteries and nobles alike.
You offer protection as a service, quietly watching for threats as money exchanges hands.
You scavenge raw tin and iron from battlefields, pulling teeth from still-twitching corpses.

table2.question: What never fails to get you out of trouble? Roll 1d6:

options.description: Fire Eggs: Six small pellets made of sea salt, wood, and crockery-dust. They explode at low heat (d8, blast) but dissipate quickly.
Black Tar: Versatile both sticky and highly flammable.
Spiked Boots: Cracks heads (d8) as easily as it does ice and muck. Travel is also a bit slower, but easier.
Tinker's Paste: Seals shut any fist-sized opening.
Fireworks: A dazzling, albeit dangerous display. Enough explosive material to blow off a finger or three.
Carrion Cat: A clever pet, small enough to hide in your pack (bulky) but strong enough to scare off smaller predators. Requires one Ration a day, and it must be meat.

background_description: Bound by blood Oath to patrol the border and protect the realm. Once sworn, the Oath cannot be broken. The Guard always finds its own.

table1.question: Why did you take the Oath?

options.description: Your family has a long tradition of serving, and you were trained from an early age on how to survive in the wild. When taking the Supply action your yield increases by one step (e.g. 1d4 > 1d6).
As a convict, the Oath was simply a means of avoiding punishment.
Noble-born, you joined to escape family trouble.
When your family lost everything, you took the Oath to avoid becoming a burden.
Your life was saved by a member of the Marchguard, and you were inspired to join their ranks.
You were in a dark place, and decided that your life needed a little direction. You're still not so sure it was the right choice.

table2.question: What do you carry as proof of your Oath?

options.description: Impressive Pin: A metal badge of honor from the Guard. It can open doors, but leaves a trail.
Oath Compass: Points not towards North, but instead to the nearest member of the Guard. It also lets you know when they're getting close.
Pullstones: Two jet-black stones. When separated, the stones will always roll in the direction of the other.
Fireflask: Highly alcoholic, yet strangely delicious. When thrown creates a wall of flames 10ft high that burns out after a few minutes.
Pain Band: Touch an injured creature to transfer their wounds to you (exchange their lost STR with your own). Recharge: Wear the ring while in perfect health. It will take 1 STR, permanently. Petty.
Poacher's Woe: Strongly-scented arrows (3 uses). The scent is powerful enough to track with ease.

background_description: Wits are your sharpest weapon, a facade your strongest shield. But when you do lose, you lose badly.

options.description: Your "patients" kept reporting miraculous recoveries, despite your lack of training. Start with a knack for healing.
After seducing a wealthy patron, their family hired a criminal gang to retrieve you. You escaped but need to lay low for a while.
You were a peddler of fake prophesies, but when one turned out to be true, it drew unwanted attention. Roll on the Omens table, but keep the result to yourself.
Your latest stunt destroyed a priceless artifact and injured a dozen bystanders.

You were cursed by a hedgewitch for fooling some innocent village folk. Magic acts unpredictably in your hands (WIL save to avoid disaster). If you are the target of magic, the same applies to its wielder.
Your "seances" with the dead were in actuality a ruse involving a cleverly hidden spellbook of Auditory Illusion. Inevitably, a patron discovered your secret.

table2.question: What keepsake could always identify you? (d6)

options.description: Born into royalty, you chose a different life. The crest grants you access, but also alerts your family of your whereabouts.
A smelly concoction that is also very, very, slippery.
A lye and ash block that makes skin temporarily transparent, revealing the anatomy within.
Derived from the placenta of a baby goat. Temporarily cures any affliction, but symptoms return within hours.
Worth 200gp, it noticeably returns to your pocket shortly after you spend it. You can't seem to get rid of it.
A dog, cat, or bird that can leave your body on demand. It follows your commands to the best of its abilities, and can pass its injuries (as STR loss) back onto you.

background_description: Your coin comes from escorting caravans, tracking fugitives, or lending your blade to a cause. You've been a savior, an executioner, a hero, and even a villain. Yours is not a solitary path, however: you'll always have your horse.

table1.question: What personal code or principle do you uphold? (d6)

options.description: No innocent blood: No bystander will come to harm on your watch. While holding this shield you cannot be moved so long as both feet are planted on firm ground.
Revere the tools of death: Weapons are to be respected and maintained.
To the death, always: You never back down from a fight, no matter the odds.
Revere the Dead: You always place two gold pieces on the eyelids of a slain foe. Somehow, you always find the coin.
Loyalty to the work: Once you've accepted a job, you see it through to the end. The stick will snap in half if the vow is ever broken.
Always pay your debts: You always repay what you owe, whether in coin or in kind. You expect nothing less from all others.
A beast built for war; an imposing creature.
Hardy and adaptable, Tough or Perilous terrain are one step easier.
Impressively strong, capable of carrying heavy loads.
Intelligent, it can understand simple commands, and even has an instinct for danger.
Highly trained and agile, it can perform intricate maneuvers in a time of need.
Wild, but very fast (even in Tough terrain). Rides light.

background_description: You are a specter in the night, a fleeting shadow that slips by its prey, unseen. Each kill a test of cunning and animal determination, a contest between life and death. You know that one day you will lose. You look forward to it.

options.description: A mock firefly, baiting water carriers with its glowing lure. Sometimes it jams.
An ice nettle, trapping and draining sheep. Don't eat it.
A silver marsh crawler that killed someone close to you. The tooth hums softly when something is stalking you.
A malicious forest spirit that poisoned a homestead.
A hollow wolf that had been frightening travellers. A great tunneler.
An azure warbler. The gametes attract a sizeable profit, if properly extracted.

table2.question: What tool is always in your pack? (d6)

options.description: Keeps you warm at the best of times, and as an explosive at the worst.
A noisy instrument that reveals nearby trails, even when deeply hidden.
A wax bar. If boiled in water, the steam acts as a soporific agent.
For traversing or securing difficult terrains, or for creating makeshift traps and structures.
A noisemaker for distracting or scaring your quarry. Sounds convincingly like a snake.
Makes any flat material (cloth, leather, sand) as hard as stone.

background_description: You sing the stories of rivers and lakes, your talents soothing friends and the elements alike. You've seen more than most, but somehow it never seems to be enough.

table1.question: What songs are you best known for? (d6)

options.description: The Tinker's Two-Step. A humorous fairy tale about a gift-giving traveler.
The Sylph and Her Lover. A bawdy tale of lost love.
Harper's Devotion. A sad, short tale about a musician that falls in love with a star.
The Reed Fisher. A celebrated song about a massive carp that always seems to get away.
Song of the Silver Stream. A wordless lullaby that mimics flowing water.
The Thrush and the Meadow. A moody tale told in alternating chorus.

table2.question: What pays your way across the land? (d6)

options.description: Performing at taverns always yields both room and board. Sometimes you even get tips!
You are a protector for those afraid to travel alone.
You buy low and sell high, always making just enough to get by.
options.special: Take a single item worth 20gp (or less) from the gear table.

options.description: You deliver "delicate" packages throughout the lands. You have at least one contact in any major town.
Whether water, wind, or sail, your aid brings ships to their destination. For you, passage is always free.
You shepherd caravans and travelers across water-soaked lands.

title: Scrivener
description: You copy ancient texts and illuminate manuscripts, recording the voices of the clever, the great, and the powerful. You will prove that the pen truly is mightier than the sword.

work_choices.description: The Wild Tongue. A bundle of leather-bound scrolls. A seminal work, cataloging the hidden languages of beasts, and how to understand them.
The Silent Symphony. Bound in fluorescent wrap. Very rare, it chronicles the subtle signs used by those employing invisibility magic.
A Treatise on the Abyss. A non-descript black book. An in-depth, largely theoretical text describing The Roots, as well as information around the location of a nearby Gate.
The Star Waltz. A comet-shaped clasp embracing a fine leather cover. Detailed astronomical charts, celestial movements, and stellar festivals. Highly valued (100gp) for its usefulness to travelers.
The Cathedral and the Canopy. Large-leaf binding over vellum. Nominally a children's storybook, the margins detail information about traveling, eating, and sleeping in the cloud forests.
Garden of Glass. Bound in the cover of another book. A heretical work, it describes the materials, procedures, and optimal locations required to open a Gate.

transcription_choices.description: Fib Ink. Glows when used to write true statements, but fades if used to write false ones.
Cipher Stone. A pair of sharp black stones. Decrypts any message written by the other.
Everquill. A quill that writes on any surface. You still need ink. Petty.
Whisper Vial. Whisper a message into the vial and it will play back to whomever opens it next.
Voyeur's Suringa. Extracts blood from a target without their knowledge. A stolen drop placed on the eye reveals memories from the past day.
Echo Leaf. A blank parchment. Whomever unfurls it sees their actions of the day slowly revealed in a tight scrawl. Petty.
